tit.cmt: タイトルなので括弧説明を削除しました。次行に補足しました

sen.j: 算道（さんどう）とは、日本律令制の大学寮において、算術・数学を研究する学科。
sen.e: Sando is a department to study arithmetic and mathematics in Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on Ritsuryo Code) in the ancient Japan.

Sando was a department for the study of arithmetic and mathematics in the Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code) in ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: Changed "is" to "was", changed "to study" to "for the study", inserted "the", inserted "the", deleted "the".
sen.e: Sando (the study of mathematics) was a department for the study of arithmetic and mathematics in the Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code) in ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: 括弧説明を補足しました

sen.j: 大宝律令による大学寮設立時から存在した学科である。
sen.e: Sando is a department existed since the establishment of Daigaku-ryo based on the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).
Sando had existed as a department since the Daigaku-ryo was established based on the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).
sen.cmt: Changed "is a department existed" to "had existed as a department", changed "the establishment of Daigaku-ryo" to "the Daigaku-ryo was established".
sen.e: Sando had existed as a department since the Daigaku-ryo was established based on the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 当初は明確な学科の種別はなかったが、一般の官人を育成するために設けられた本科に相当する儒教の講義（後の明経道にあたる）以外には、儒教経典の原典をそのまま筆記するための書道 (大学寮)とそのまま発音するための音道は本科の補完するためのものであった。
sen.e: Initially there was no clear-cut type of department and other than the Confucian lecture (later Myogyo-do (study of Confucian classics)), which was equivalent to the regular course established to educate general government officials, Shodo (calligraphy) to write down the original Confucian scripture as it is (Daigaku-ryo) and Ondo to pronounce that as it is were to complement the regular course.

Initially there were no clearly defined departments, but the course established to educate general government officials consisted mainly of Confucian lectures (later Myogyo-do (the study of Confucian classics)), complemented by Shodo (calligraphy), which involved writing down the original Confucian scriptures verbatim (Daigaku-ryo), and Ondo, learning to pronounce them correctly.
sen.cmt: Rewrote.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: それに対して算道の扱う分野は儒教とは直接的な関連性はなく、計算や測量などの技術系官人の育成を行うことを目的としていたことから、唯一本科から独立した存在であったのが算道であった。
sen.e: While the area treated by Sando had no direct relevance to the Confucianism and aimed at educating technical government officials for calculation, survey, and others, thereby Sando was the only existence independent from the regular course.

In contrast, the fields covered by Sando had no direct relevance to Confucianism and aimed at educating technical government officials in calculation, survey, and other similar subjects; in this way, Sando was the only existence independent from the regular course.

sen.e: In contrast, the fields covered by Sando had no direct relevance to Confucianism and aimed at educating technical government officials in calculation, survey, and other similar subjects; in this way, Sando was the only existence independent from the regular course.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大学寮には算道を教授する算博士（さんはかせ、従七位上相当・2名）と学生である算生（さんしょう、30名）で構成されていた。
sen.e: Daigaku-ryo consisted of San hakase (Doctor of Numbers, equivalent to Jushichiijo (Junior Seventh Rank, Upper Grade), two people) who taught Sando, and Sansho (student studying arithmetic, thirty people).
The Daigaku-ryo consisted of two San hakase (Doctor of Numbers, equivalent to Jushichiijo (Junior Seventh Rank, Upper Grade)) who taught Sando, and thirty Sansho (students studying arithmetic).

sen.e: The Daigaku-ryo consisted of two San hakase (Doctor of Numbers, equivalent to Jushichiijo (Junior Seventh Rank, Upper Grade)) who taught Sando, and thirty Sansho (students studying arithmetic).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これは唐の国子監に置かれた算学と同数であり、教授として博士1名以外に助教2名及び複数名の直講が置かれて、学生も400名もいた本科と比べると小さいものの、唐の国子監の規模は日本の大学寮と比べて大きいこと、唐の算学博士は従九品下と低い地位に置かれたことを考えれば、設置当初の地位は一概に低いとは言えなかったとされている。
sen.e: These numbers are the same as those of Sangaku (study of mathematics) set in Kokushikan (educational ministry) of Tang dynasty in China, and it had one doctor as a professor, two associate professors, and a few chokko (lecturer) people, which was smaller than the regular course with four hundred students, but not categorically in the low position when it was initially set considering that Tang's Kokushikan was larger than the Japanese Daigaku-ryo and Tang's San hakase was put in the low position of Jukuhonge (Junior Ninth Rank, Lower Grade).

These numbers are the same as those of the Sangaku (study of mathematics) in the Kokushikan (educational ministry) of Tang dynasty China, which had one doctor as professor, two associate professors, and a few chokko (lecturers); while the Sando was smaller than the regular course, which had four hundred students, it is thought not to have been categorically in a low position during its early days, considering that the Tang's Kokushikan was larger than the Japanese Daigaku-ryo, and that the Tang's San hakase was put in the low position of Jukuhonge (Junior Ninth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: Inserted "the", changed "set in" to "in the", removed "in", changed "and it" to "which", removed "a", changed "lecturer" to "lecturers", deleted "people", inserted semicolon, changed "which" to "while", changed "it" to "the Sando", rewrote end of sentence.
sen.e: These numbers are the same as those of the Sangaku (study of mathematics) in the Kokushikan (educational ministry) of Tang Dynasty, China, which had one doctor as professor, two associate professors, and a few chokko (lecturers); while the Sando was smaller than the regular course, which had four hundred students, it is thought not to have been categorically in a low position during its early days, considering that the Tang's Kokushikan was larger than the Japanese Daigaku-ryo, and that the Tang's San hakase was put in the low position of Jukuhonge (Junior Ninth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: また、天平宝字元年（757年）からは陰陽寮で暦道を学ぶ暦生の中から暦学に必要な数学を学ぶために算道を兼修する暦算生が別枠として設置された。
sen.e: Furthermore, among Reki no sho (student of calendar) who were learning rekido (study of calendar) at Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination), rekisansho was set as another quota to also learn Sando to study mathematics required for rekido from 757.

Furthermore, starting in 757, "rekisansho", a combination of calender study and Sando, was set up as another division so that Reki no sho (students of calendar) who were learning rekido (calendar study) at the Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination) could learn the mathematics required for rekido.

sen.j: 養老律令では方法が2通りあり、前者は『九章算術』3問と『六章』・『綴術』以外の残り6書から各1問の計9問から出題されるもの、後者は『六章』3問と『綴術』6問の計9問から出題されるもので、前者は基礎算術、後者は高等数学の知識を試した。
sen.e: While there were two ways in the Yoro Code, and the total nine questions were delivered in one of the ways, three questions of "Kyushosanjutsu" and one from each of the remaining six documents other than "Rokusho" and "Tenjutsu", and the total nine questions were delivered in the other way, three questions of "Rokusho" and six of "Tenjutsu", and the former tested knowledge of basic arithmetics and the latter, that of advanced mathematics.

There were two methods in the Yoro Code, each of which delivered a total of nine questions: in the first, three questions were drawn from the "Kyushosanjutsu" with each of the remaining documents other than "Rokusho" and "Tenjutsu" providing one of the other six; in the second, three questions were drawn from "Rokusho" and the remaining six from "Tenjutsu", so that the former method tested knowledge of basic arithmetic while the latter tested knowledge of advanced mathematics.

sen.j: 算得業生成立後は、7年学習して奉試に及第すると合格者は算博士や主計寮・主税寮・大宰府・造宮省（後には修理職・木工寮）に設置されていた算師に任じられる他、地方の下級国司となって租税会計事務などを扱った。
sen.e: After the establishment of San tokugosho, those who learned for seven years and passed Hoshi were appointed to San hakase and Sanshi (a court official in charge of calculation) set in Syukeiryo (account office), Shuzeiryo (bureau of taxation), Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), and Zogusho (ministry of making and mending palaces) (later Shurishiki (The Palace Repairs Office) and Mokuryo (Bureau of Carpentry), and also became a lower provincial governor to handle land tax accountancy and others.

sen.e: At that time, arithmetic did not spread and few people had its knowledge, thereby various government officials greatly expected Sansho's mathematical processing ability, who passed the examination and became government officials even though the official court rank was low.

At that time, arithmetic was not widespread and few people had such knowledge; therefore, although the official court rank of the Sansho was low, once they passed the examination and became government officials, various government officials held great expectations for their mathematical processing abilities.

sen.e: However, it was arithmetic and mathematics as skill, and mathematical thinking, cultivation, and sensibility were not asked for, let alone it seems that advanced mathematics seen in China was not required for the Japanese society of that time and it could not become an opportunity for the Japanese history of mathematics to uniquely progress.

sen.j: 大学寮が設置された当初、一般官人を育てる本科（明経道）と技術官人を育てる算道しか事実上存在していなかったが、神亀年間に律令を教える律学博士（後の明法博士）と歴史を教える文章博士が明経道から分離する形で成立し、やがて天平年間に独立した学科となり、後の明法道・紀伝道へと発展することとなる。
